II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
In 2001, the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic requested from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) technical assistance1 (TA) for preparing the Second Education Project (the Project) 
as a follow-up to the Education Sector Development Program (ESDP).2 The Project is included 
in the 2004 Country Strategy and Program Update 2005–2006,3 which prioritizes investments in 
education and early childhood development as important means of achieving poverty reduction. 
The project design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

The  education  system  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  follows  the  Soviet  model  of  11  years  of 
3. 
general  education.  Primary  education  (grades  1–4)  begins  at  age  6  or  7.  Lower  secondary 
(basic)  education  comprises  grades  5–9.  Basic  education  is  compulsory.  Upper  secondary 
education  includes  grades  10–11.  The  Ministry  of  Education  (MOE)  is  responsible  for  setting 
education  policy  and  standards,  and  it  controls  implementation  through  oblast  (province) 
departments  of  education  and  raion  (district)  departments  of  education.  Aiyil  okmotu  (village 
authorities)  administer  their  schools  and  are  responsible  for  allocating  resources  for  school 
operation and maintenance (O&M). The structure of the education system is in Appendix 2. 
 
4. 
There  are  2,045  general  education  schools  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  of  which  351  are 
urban  and  1,694  rural.  Of  these,  1,614  schools  used  a  single  language  of  instruction  (Kyrgyz, 
Russian,  or  Uzbek)  in  2004,  and  431  schools  used  two  or  more  languages  of  instruction 
(Kyrgyz,  Russian,  Uzbek,  and/or  Tajik).  In  school  year  (SY)  2004,  most  general  education 
schools—1,525,  or  75%—operated  in  two  shifts.  In  addition,  105  schools  with  a  total  of  about 
18,100 students operated in three shifts. The number of children with special needs in inclusive 
classes was 250 in SY2004. An analysis of the education sector is in Appendix 3. 
 
5. 
The education reforms started in the Kyrgyz Republic in 1993, emphasizing accessibility 
for all children without exception.4 Following independence in 1991, macroeconomic conditions 
in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic deteriorated  dramatically,  resulting  in  a  50%  decline  in  gross  domestic 
product (GDP). In 1996, these trends reversed, and annual economic growth averaged 5% from 
1997  to  2004.  Economic  transition  has  had  major  implications  for  the  financing  of  education. 
The  education  budget  declined  sharply  in  the  early  1990s  and  gradually  started  to  increase 
again in 1999. In real terms, education expenditure was increased gradually from $63.7 million 
in 1999 to $91.4 million in 2004, and it is projected to increase about 2% annually in 2005–2007. 
By share of GDP, education expenditure has increased gradually from 4.0% in 1999 to 4.3% in 
2004, and it is expected to exceed 5.0% by 2010. Education expenditure as percentage of the 
national  budget  varied  from  a  low  of  19.8%  in  2000  to  a  high  of  22.2%  in  2003  but  is 
consistently the largest single item in the national budget.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Primary and General Secondary Education Subsector Issues 

 
Need for a New Curriculum.6 Prior to independence, the curriculum was consistent with 
9. 
that of the Soviet Union. Following independence, the Kyrgyz Republic revised the curriculum in 
1992.  Notable  among  the  many  minor  changes  since  1992  are  the  introduction  of  foreign 
languages into primary school, the replacement of environmental studies with homeland studies 
and  of  Soviet  history  with  that  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  and  the  introduction  of  information  and 
communications  technology  (ICT)  courses,  as  well  as  of  ethics.  A  set  of  state  educational 
standards, developed in 1996 and subsequently revised in 2002 and 2004, are still in draft form 
awaiting the Government’s consideration. The current curriculum comprises 24 subjects. While 
it  differs  somewhat  from  the  old  Soviet  curriculum,  particularly  persistent  is  the  tradition  of 
heavily content-based subjects. 
 
10.  MOE  is  considering  lengthening  the  general  education  system  to  12  years  from  the 
present  11  years  and  the  question  of  whether  the  proposed  additional  year  would  follow  the 
existing 11 years or precede it as an additional preschool year. The need is urgent to introduce 
a modern curriculum that not only reflects the national context of education but also ensures a 
student-centered  approach,  supported  by  modern  learning  materials  and  a  modern  learning-
assessment system, and implemented by highly qualified educators. 
 
11.

12. 
The Government policy is to provide textbooks and learning materials to all students in 
general education (grades 1–11) in the four approved languages of instruction: Kyrgyz, Russian, 
Tajik, and  Uzbek.  Out  of  1.144  million  students  enrolled  in 2004,  716,572  use  Kyrgyz  as  their 
language  of  instruction,  273,223  use  Russian,  151,163  use  Uzbek,  and  only  3,078  use  Tajik. 
Most  of  the  materials  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  have  been  translated  from  Russian,  with  the 
notable  exceptions  of  textbooks  on  the  history  and  geography  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  which 
were developed under the ESDP. In the years immediately following independence, textbooks 
in  Uzbek  and  Tajik  were  imported  from  Uzbekistan7  and  Tajikistan.  The  Osh  Center  of 
Adaptation  of  Textbooks  in  the  Uzbek  language  was  engaged  under  the  ESDP  to  develop 
textbooks for students studying in Uzbek in the Kyrgyz Republic. 
 
13. 
Free  distribution  of  textbooks  to  enrolled  students  was  discontinued  in  1994  due  to 
severe  constraints  on  expenditures.  In  1999,  the  Government,  with  support  from  the  ESDP, 
introduced a textbook rental scheme (TRS) to address the resulting problems of access to and 
affordability  of  textbooks,  in  particular  for  the  poor.  Under  the  TRS,  textbooks  are  rented  to 
students for Som15 ($0.37) per book per year in Bishkek city and Chui oblast, and for Som12 
($0.29) elsewhere in the country, with a waiver of rental fees for students whose parents cannot 
afford  to  pay.  The  TRS  is  complex  and  needs  reform  to  make  it  more  effective.  The  World 
Bank’s  Rural  Education  Project  (REP)8  is  supporting  Government  efforts  to  further  refine  the 
TRS and develop commercial textbook production initiated under the ESDP. It is envisaged that 
a textbook approval board independent of KAE will be established under the REP.

17.  Weak  Incentives  for  the  Teaching  Profession.  The  shortage  of  qualified  teachers, 
particularly in rural schools,  an aging teaching corps, and the inability of the education system 
to provide adequate in-service training are key constraints on improving the quality of education. 
All three problems stem from insufficient funding, the resultant low salaries for teachers, and the 
consequent declining incentives, morale, and motivation within the teaching profession. A large 
and increasing number of teachers are over the age of 45. Recruiting qualified new teachers to 
replace retirees is proving difficult primarily due to very low salaries. Salaries for teachers and 
principals are usually well below the average monthly wage, and even the top monthly salary of 
Som9769 ($23.8) is below the poverty level of Som1,144 ($27.9) calculated using the minimum 
consumer basket approach. Salary increases for teachers are critically important for improving 
teacher  morale  and  attracting  young  teachers,  particularly  to  schools  in  rural  areas.  The 
Government increased teachers’ salaries by 15% in April 2004 and a further increase of almost 
15% was approved in October 2004, leading to a cumulative increase of 30% in 2004. However, 
teachers’ salaries remain very low, and teachers are reluctant to undertake assignments in rural 
schools. Teachers also have little motivation to improve their performance, as doing so does not 
bring  salary  increases  or  other  forms  of  professional  recognition.  A  new  promotion  scheme 
based on performance will be supported under the World Bank’s REP.

from 12.9:1 in Naryn oblast to 19.0:1 in Bishkek. Serious shortages of teachers affect schools in

but  not  the  primary  level.  A  2003  study  conducted  by  the  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund

geography,  physics,  biology,  foreign  languages,  and  ICT  were  not  conducted  due  to  teacher 
shortages in rural areas. Teacher shortages often arise from the inability of the education sector 
to compete with the private sector in attracting personnel with such skills.

SY2004,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic’s  1,694  rural  schools  (82%  of  all  schools  in  the  country)  served 
816,337  students  (70%  of  all  students).  The  enrollment  rate  in  general  education  rose  from 
86.9%  in  1998  to  90.6%  in  2002,  but  in  primary  schools  enrollment  declined  from  98.7%  to 
96.8%  in  the  same  period.  The  drop  was  steepest  for  boys,  from  98.1%  to  95.8%.  Rates  for

22.  MOE  statistics  indicate  that  the  total  number  of  children  not  attending  school  declined 
from  3,516  in  SY2001  to  1,344  in  SY2004.  However,  many  enrolled  students  do  not  attend 
school  for  extended  periods.  A  study  conducted  by  UNICEF10  in  1999  indicates  that  this  is 
particularly  true  for  students  in  poor,  remote,  and  mountainous  areas.  Declining  attendance

lack of learning materials, aids, and equipment. In addition, children from poor families drop out 
of  school  in  grade  7  or  8  to  help  support  to  the  household.  These  hidden  dropouts  from  the 
system reflect serious participation and efficiency problems.

The  education  system  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  follows  the  Soviet  model  of  11  years  of

education (grades 1–4) begins at age 6 or 7. Lower secondary education covers grades 5 to 9.

education to all children.  
 
2. 
In 2002, 9.5% of children 1–6 years of age were enrolled in 416 preschools, down from 
about one in four enrolled before independence. Urban enrollment was 24.7%, and rural 3.8%. 
In 2002, 96.8% of the primary school age group was enrolled in primary schools (97.8% of boys,

girls). Enrollment in upper secondary education was 72.0% (68% of boys, 76.1% of girls).

and  administer  vocational,  technical,  and  higher  education.  Raion  (district)  departments  of

11.  Management improvement needs to continue both nationally and locally. National policy

8  of  the  main  text)  will  provide  support  for,  and  build  the  capacity  of,  staff  in  these  new  units.

directors and school committees.

3. 

Education Expenditure 

 
15. 
In  2002,  4.5%  of  the  consolidated  republican  (central  and  regional)  budget,  or 
Som3,350,400,  was  allocated  to  education.  This  was  an  increase  from  2000  (3.5%)  but  a 
decrease  from  1998  (4.9%).4  Between  75%  and  80%  of  the  budget  of  MOE  pays  teachers’ 
salaries.  Allocation  of  the  remaining  amount  is  at  the  discretion  of  the  MOE,  most  often  for 
recurrent  expenditures.  General  education  (grades  1–11)  receives  the  majority  of  education 
expenditures (nearly 70% in 2001) and will continue to do so. More emphasis, however, will be 
placed  upon  preschool  education  and  vocational  and  technical  education  in  the  next  medium-
term plan.  
 
16.  Most capital expenditures are financed by donors (who provided Som45 million in 2003). 
Other education expenditures are financed by the regional administrations in oblasts and raions. 
Approximately  35%  of  the  resources  raised  locally  through  taxes  are  sent  to  the  center  for 
reallocation. Naryn, Talas, and Batken oblasts are in deficit, with income at only about 30% of 
expenditures. Another significant resource of school funding is parental contributions.  
 
17. 
School  Recurrent  Expenditure  and  Per  Capita  Cost.  On  average,  66%  of  the  total 
expenditure  on  vocational  education  comes  from  the  state  budget,  and  the  balance  of  34% 
comes from parental contributions. In higher education, parental contributions averaged 59% of 
the  total  expenditures  during  the  past  4  years,  and  only  41%  came  from  the  state  budget.  A 
tenth of the students in higher education are on scholarship programs financed by the state, and 
the rest have to pay tuition fees averaging Som16,000 per year per student. Data on financing 
recurrent expenditures on education from 2001 to 2004 are presented in Table A3.3 below. 
 
18. 
Although the state budget is the major source of financing for the education system, data 
on parental contributions during the last 4 school years—averaging 9% of total expenditures in 
preschool  and  6%  in  general  secondary  education—shows  that  the  share  of  community 
contributions  toward  financing  the  education  system  has  been  constant,  except  for  slight 
decrease  of  1  percentage  point  during  SY2002  and  SY2003  in  preschool  education  and  an 
increase of the same size in the same school years for general secondary school (Table A3.3).  
 
19. 
Parental  contributions  to  vocational  education  and  higher  education  were  maintained 
from  2001  to  2003  but  declined  in  2004  by  17%  and  22%,  respectively.  It  should  be  noted, 
however,  that  the  annual  budget  allocated  by  the  Government  to  finance  the  whole  education 
system from 2001 to 2004 consistently met the annual recurrent expenditures financed from the 
state budget.

1. 
Education  staff  in  countries  of  the  former  Soviet  Union  typically  have  had  minimal 
exposure  to  other  approaches  to  education  that  are  perhaps  more  innovative  and  effective. 
Many view their education system is quite satisfactory as it is. At the same time, they feel the 
need  to  align  their  education  systems  more  closely  with  those  of  other  countries.  To  help 
overcome  this  lack  of  exposure,  short  external  training  programs  and  longer  overseas  degree 
programs  can  be  provided.  The  Project  will  provide  a  specially  designed  1-month  training 
program for 28 participants in two groups. Its objective is to provide participants with a thorough 
understanding  of  approaches  and  recent  innovations  in  curriculum  development,  learning 
assessment, and teacher training used in other countries. Participants will use this experience 
to develop the best means of modernizing their education system.   
 
2. 
The Project will recruit an international consulting firm expert in curriculum development, 
textbook  and  learning  materials,  learning  assessment,  and  teacher  training.  It  will  initiate 
capacity development in the Kyrgyz Academy of Education’s National Teacher Training Institute 
(NTTI) and seven oblast teacher training institutes (TTIs) by reviewing their current approaches 
for  curriculum  development,  classroom  assessment,  and  teacher  training,  and  their  need  for 
exposure to alternatives. The consulting firm will then develop a 1-month training program to be 
delivered at each institution for two groups of 14 specialists each. The first group will focus on 
curriculum  development  and  learning  assessment,  and  the  second  on  teacher  training 
methodology.  These  28  specialists  will  form  a  core  group  to  develop  the  new  curriculum  and

foster homes for children. During 1997–2000, Som3.3 million were allocated to foster homes.
